Attention Jackson County residents. Do you have hazardous waste cluttering your space? The Jackson County Conservation District is hosting their hazardous waste collection July 25th from 1 to 6 p.m. at the Jackson County Department of Transportation lot on the corner of Channer and Elm. Cost is $20 per vehicle to safely dispose of your hazardous materials. Visit jacksoncd.org to register and view the list of accepted items. Clean up your space, protect the environment, and join us July 25th for the hazardous waste collection brought to you by the Jackson County Conservation District.

WKHM Newstime 733. We're delighted to welcome to the program County Clerk, Sierra Soule, in the house. Good morning. Good morning. Thank you so much for having me. Welcome. She's going to talk about early voting, but she's on the ballot. Now, you replaced Amanda Kirkpatrick. Yes, I did. Right? Yes. So how did that, what happened there? Yeah. Because you weren't elected, right? Appointed, correct. You were appointed. Mm-hmm.

By the county board? By the circuit court judges of Jackson County. Oh, okay. Yeah. So last April, Clerk Kirkpatrick decided she was going to retire. And the circuit court judges of Jackson County did decide that unanimously appoint me as county clerk and register of deeds. So I've been in this role since May 1st of 2023. But you've been...

Bumming around the county for a long time, right? Yes, yes. So I've actually worked for the county for 17 years. I started in the Jackson County Prosecutor's Office as a high school intern, and I worked my way up to Chief Administrative Services. Throughout the years, I worked with Prosecutor Hank Zavaslak. You may remember him.

Oh, I remember them quite well. Most people in Jackson do. Rest in peace. Yes. And then I worked for Prosecutor Jerry Jarzynka for a period of time as a Chief Administrative Services. And then Clerk Patrick reached out to me in 2021 and asked if I would be interested to replace her Chief Deputy County Clerk who was retiring.

and I decided that was a good move. It was something different, and it was definitely a challenge, and it's been a delightful challenge ever since, fulfilling every possible need I need. Yeah, a lot of challenges in the clerk's office, especially with the way voting has seemed to now change, and there's new rules and regulations. You've got to be

not only on top of it you almost have to be ahead of what's happening you really do the spotlight is really on um election officials and you know we do a great job at making sure that we're we're following the law and with these new changes that occurred because of proposal 22-2 in november of 2022 voters voted in this constitutional amendment

which basically gives all voters the right to vote early in every statewide and federal election. And so municipalities can enter into an agreement with the county. They can enter into an agreement with another municipality, so do it as a joint, or they can do it on their own.

And so here in Jackson County, what we have happening is 16 of the 20 jurisdictions in our county have went with the county coordinated sites. So what that means is only four, which are the City of Jackson, Columbia Charter Township, Sandstone Township, and Spring Arbor Township, those two have gone together, but the other two have gone alone. All other jurisdictions have gone with the countywide site.

So, myself, my elections director, my team, we all prepare and host and coordinate two sites, one at Blackman Township and one at Summit Township, for any voter of those 16 jurisdictions to go and vote at. So, you're going grocery shopping, you are running an errand with your family. Now, this is the early voting, right? This is early voting. Okay.
Yep. So nine days before every statewide and federal election show for August 6th, it's July 27th through August 4th. So you can go to Blackmon or Summit. Yes.

Vote. Period. Yep. The entire ballot. Yes. Yada, yada, yada. Absolutely. And what's even more pleasant about this is that you could take your AV ballot, so your absentee ballot that you received at home through the mail. You could look at your ballot while you're drinking your coffee, eating your breakfast, and then you can come into an early voting site or even on election day and you can vote that absentee ballot in person through the tabulator. So people have taken the opportunity to do that as well.

So can you fill it out at home and just bring it in? Yes, absolutely. No issues there? No issues. Obviously, the election inspectors will check you in and make sure that you are able to vote at that site. Now, you still have to have a...

license or picture id right you don't have to bring a lawyer or anything no lawyer no not at all make sure you bring an id we also bodyguard no bodyguards okay fortunately in jackson county everyone has been very pleasant very nice so we don't have a lot of issues this is a nice nice county yes it truly is people ask all the time how is it in jackson county honestly we don't have very many issues with elections um people behave themselves appropriately and i'm thankful for that

So take me to election night. How has it changed since you've come in there? Because some nights, I know I have to spend all night here waiting for those results. Some nights they get in early and sometimes...

Let's just say the media is frustrated. I know you're frustrated. And I'm sure you're frustrated. I'm frustrated. Okay. There have been times where I don't leave the office until 3.45 a.m. And that could just be a variance of things needing to make sure that signatures are done and...

things are closed appropriately and those sort of things. It can vary from being done very early, as you mentioned. So in a smaller election where we just have maybe one school proposal, that can be a really quick night for us. But if we have every single jurisdiction participating, that can take a little bit longer to get all those results in. Mm-hmm. Yeah, see that couch out there? That's where I end up usually. I may need a couch too. On election night. So...

What are the issues you deal with, Sierra, on election night? I think on election night and in general, misinformation is a lot of the issues that we deal with or people that don't understand the process. They don't understand that elections are a bipartisan thing, it has to say. So you have Republicans and Democrats from each party looking at everything, doing everything as a team together.

We do a lot of testing as well, right? I had public accuracy tests on Monday the 15th and we tested the equipment. We tested the equipment before the public accuracy test. We tested it before the test. So these machines go through a lot of testing and people don't understand that and aren't involved in that process.

so i encourage everyone to look at the facebook page my facebook page you can follow me for updates we do post when we have these tests i would love to see the public there i would love to see people asking questions would love to see people at our canvas so the canvas always starts the thursday after the tuesday election at 9 a.m again these things are on my website they're on my facebook page please come familiarize yourself with the process get educated would love to to learn love to

educate the entire public about this. Who makes sure the machines are correct or, I don't know, double check maybe? Yeah, a variety of people. Okay. A lot of people. A lot of people want to see that? Yes, yep. So how does that work? I mean, you don't let any, just... No, no. Joe Belota can't come in. No, don't touch the equipment. So, for example... I mean, you feel it's extremely reliable, right? I do, I do.

For example, on Monday when we did the public accuracy test, we had our election commission. So our chief judge and our county treasurer, myself, we personally tested these machines, which means that we fed ballots into the machine, that we knew what the results were going to be because we had the predetermined chart of results in front of us.

And what that means is we look at the results at the end and we compare it to what it should be and it matches perfectly every time. And if it weren't to match perfectly, we would make sure we figured that out before we went to election night or elections. Say it's 99.8%.

Correct. Is there an oversight? No, that's never happened in my experience. Really? In my experience, that's never happened, especially when we do post-election audits, right? So I do audits. Well, we do audits. And we hand count the ballots to compare it to how the machine tabulated them, and it comes out exactly the same every time. Yeah, because when you say every vote counts, especially around here, we've had some –
elections that are single digit differences. Some of the smaller races, really.

Right. And so people have an opportunity per the law to do a recount. And we conducted one recently that I can recall. And the person that requested this recount, the results turned out exactly as tabulated. And again, this person had the opportunity to watch people hand count these ballots. And they were very satisfied with how it came out with a hand count because it was exactly as the tabulator had tabulated. So you take every...
Every vote? Everything. Hand counting? We did. Is that? In an audit. Arduous? Or a recall. Yes. My eyes are usually crossed by the end.

So you didn't sign up for this. What are your thoughts after, you know, a couple years of doing this? Yeah, so being a county clerk in registered deeds is a lot of work. It's very fulfilling. As far as elections, elections are a lot of work. And unless you work in them. Yeah, but you don't get, Sierra, you don't get any credit. You're behind the scenes. I am, yeah.

I like helping people. That's my number one thing. And actually, I had a gentleman, I had just done a presentation. I'd gone down to the first floor of the tower building and this man looked like he didn't know where he was going or what was going on. And I asked, do you need help? And I always ask people, do you need help? How can I help you? And he said, I can't go up the elevator. I'm deathly afraid of the elevator. I said, well, what service are you trying to get? And it was one of my services.

And so I took his paperwork, helped him out, took it upstairs, processed it, got him his change, brought it all back down. And he thanked me immensely because he could not go up the elevator. And I love helping people. So that's why I got into this is to help people. So you're on the ballot being challenged by Sabrina Brownlow on August 6th.
My race is actually in November. Oh, okay. Yes. So you're the Republican. I am. And she's the Democrat. Yes. So you're not on...

Well, thank goodness you're not on the August 6th. You will see my name and I would always appreciate the vote. Yeah. So you can vote for Clark. Yes. On August 6th. Yes. And you will see my signs out. And I've been working hard. I've been going to a lot of events and meeting a lot of public and honestly getting a lot of really good feedback. So I feel like I'm doing a really good job based on the feedback I'm getting. Mm hmm.

So is this something you want to make a long career out of? Yes, I believe so. The clerk's job, like I said, is much more than I thought it would be. It's much more challenging than I thought it would be. When I see the word clerk or when other people see the word clerk, it's almost not as respected as it should be. Exactly. And I don't understand that because the job that I have is a large and vast amount of responsibilities.

And so I oversee all four circuit court records. So I oversee all births, deaths, marriage, CPL, DBA, DD 214s, notaries, all elections, obviously. I oversee there. I am also the register of deeds, right? So I'm a dual role. What does that encompass? Just the register of deeds?

Yeah, so it's land records. So registering all land records in Jackson County. Oh, and those can be a nightmare, can't they? Yes. Tricky? Yes, very tricky. And we also have to make sure everyone meets the Michigan recording requirements. So unfortunately, we do have to reject documents, just as we do at the courthouse, when they don't meet the minimum filing standards according to MCR 1.09D. So I know that went off the top of my head there. Okay.

So how do you work with the judges? Very well. Very well. Like I said, I was appointed unanimously, so I get along very well. We work through issues. As you know, the court can be a long process to get a case through, work well with them in terms of there's an issue. Some of the judges will come right down to my office and talk about it, or I'll go right up to their office and we'll talk about it. So we get along very well.

So if somebody wants like a court file or documents, they go through you, right? Yes, that is my office, correct. The Fourth Circuit Court Clerk. Constitutional, that is, requirement. How do you do it? My husband says, I don't see you very often.

So you're a Vandy girl. I am. Yeah, I went to high school just down the street. I actually worked right over here at Polly's Country Market for a while. So, yeah, I'm from Jackson. I went to Spring Arbor University for my bachelor's degree in management and organizational development. And then I went on to pursue a master's in business administration from Spring Arbor University as well, all while working full time, of course, for the prosecutor's office. So that has really shaped who I am today.

So do you take time to sleep before August 6th? No. No? No. Is that hectic going up to the date? Yes, it is very hectic. So we have to make sure we have enough ballots ordered. We have to make sure our equipment has been tested. We have to make sure that we have election inspectors. We have to make sure that their orientation, we have their I-9s, all the things that are done behind the scenes. It's quite a bit of work.

And I'm glad that 16 of the 20 jurisdictions have gone with the countywide with trusting me to help coordinate this. But it's a significant impact on our workload. As you know, the county runs lean. The clerk's office runs very lean. Yeah.

In February alone, I can account for my staff working just on early voting over 690 hours that I can account for. So there's plenty of hours that we can account for. So this is an immensely amount of work for our office.

So do you need more help? Yes. You do? Yes. Okay. Like full-time? I would love additional full-time positions. Shotwell's usually listening. Well, here's my plug for that. There you go. We need more people. Need more people. Yes, always need more people.

Now, will this get busier or crazier in November? Yes, I am anticipating these things to continue on. So between August and November, we have a lot of deadlines. In fact, we have deadlines beginning the day after the election for November.

So we're not even done with August because we have Canvas that starts on the Thursday after the August election. And we have deadlines starting that day after and then continuing on. So while we're conducting the Canvas, we are also still trying to prepare for November. So it is very, very tight for us to get this work done. Well, you better rest up because you got a couple.

I'll rest in the end of November. Busy months coming up. Yes. Well, great to have you out. Well, thank you for having me. And I stole your phone number, so. You got it. If we need to get a hold of you. Anytime. No issue. Sierra Soule is a county clerk here in Jackson County, and she will be on the ballot but unchallenged on the August 6th and will be.

I'm predicting my exit polling that you will win. You will pass the musker August 6th, so she'll be on the ballot in November as well. Good luck. Thanks. Thank you, Craig. See if Shotwell comes through for you.
